articles.headline: Ex-A.I.G. Chief Wins Bailout Suit, but Gets No Damages
articles.snippet: Maurice Greenberg, the former chief of A.I.G., had been seeking nearly $40 billion, contending that the government overstepped its bounds in its 2008 bailout.
articles.abstract: Maurice Greenberg, the former chief of A.I.G., had been seeking nearly $40 billion, contending that the government overstepped its bounds in its 2008 bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, brought a class-action lawsuit against the government in 2011, contending that the Federal Reserve overstepped its bounds when it bailed out his company at the height of the financial crisis, the reaction was mainly befuddlement and outright ridicule.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Plans to Offer Consumer Loans Online, Adopting Start-Ups’ Tactics
articles.snippet: The unit will eliminate the costs of bank branches and tellers to allow Goldman to charge lower interest rates and still make a profit. But the venture holds risks.
articles.abstract: The unit will eliminate the costs of bank branches and tellers to allow Goldman to charge lower interest rates and still make a profit. But the venture holds risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has spent 146 years largely as the bank of the powerful and privileged.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: A Thirsty Colorado Is Battling Over Who Owns Raindrops
articles.snippet: The debate over collecting rain in barrels, which is illegal in the state, is a microcosm of fights across the region over who should get to keep using water and who should have to cut back.
articles.abstract: The debate over collecting rain in barrels, which is illegal in the state, is a microcosm of fights across the region over who should get to keep using water and who should have to cut back.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Jason Story bought an old soy sauce barrel to collect the rain dripping from his downspout, he figured he had found an environmentally friendly way to water his garden’s beets and spinach. But under the quirks of Western water rules, where raindrops are claimed even as they tumble from the sky, he became a water outlaw.

articles.headline: Gap Is Closing 175 Stores, Hoping for a Turnaround
articles.snippet: Gap’s cuts could affect thousands of jobs, as the brand struggles to revive a business mired in a long sales slump.
articles.abstract: Gap’s cuts could affect thousands of jobs, as the brand struggles to revive a business mired in a long sales slump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gap announced on Monday that it planned to close one-fourth of its stores in North America over the next few years, potentially affecting thousands of jobs, as the brand struggles to turn around a business mired in a long sales slump.

articles.headline: Siena Tries to Regain Its Financial Footing, and Its Identity
articles.snippet: Monte dei Paschi, the world’s oldest bank, was the center of life in Siena, Italy. So when it nearly collapsed, the city was left scrambling to fill the void.
articles.abstract: Monte dei Paschi, the world’s oldest bank, was the center of life in Siena, Italy. So when it nearly collapsed, the city was left scrambling to fill the void.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — Operators of kindergartens and ambulance services had to find new sources of funds. A biotech company filed for bankruptcy. The local professional soccer team slipped into the minor leagues after it could no longer afford the salaries of its top players.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Gaia Pianigiani

articles.headline: In A.I.G. Case, Surprise Ruling That Could End All Bailouts
articles.snippet: A decision that the Fed acted beyond its legal authority in bailing out A.I.G. could have far-reaching consequences should another financial crisis occur — and if history is any guide, one will.
articles.abstract: A decision that the Fed acted beyond its legal authority in bailing out A.I.G. could have far-reaching consequences should another financial crisis occur — and if history is any guide, one will.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, critics of the bailouts during the financial crisis argued that the rescue efforts weren’t harsh enough. The chief executives of failing institutions should have lost their jobs. Shareholders should have suffered more pain. Taxpayers should have received substantial compensation for the risk they took.

articles.headline: Offering Services, ISIS Digs In Deeper in Seized Territories
articles.snippet: The jihadists’ governing efforts, from inspecting food to offering perks to newlyweds, have brought a stability unavailable from national governments.
articles.abstract: The jihadists’ governing efforts, from inspecting food to offering perks to newlyweds, have brought a stability unavailable from national governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — In northern Syria, the jihadists of the Islamic State have fixed power lines, dug sewage systems and painted sidewalks. In Raqqa, they search markets and slaughterhouses for expired food and sick animals. Farther south, in Deir al-Zour, they have imposed taxes on farmers and shopkeepers and fined men for wearing short beards.

articles.headline: Rachel Dolezal, in Center of Storm, Is Defiant: ‘I Identify as Black’
articles.snippet: As Ms. Dolezal has refused to back down on her embrace of black identity, some people have applauded her work and others have deplored her methods and actions.
articles.abstract: As Ms. Dolezal has refused to back down on her embrace of black identity, some people have applauded her work and others have deplored her methods and actions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — When she moved into her uncle’s basement in the largely white town of Coeur d’Alene, Idaho, in 2004, Rachel A. Dolezal was still blond and pale-skinned and identified herself as a white woman — one who had left a black husband and had a biracial child.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson, Richard Pérez-Peña and John Eligon
